entries.name: Sentry's Rest
entries: You can finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in 6 hours if you spend those hours in an inactive, motionless state, during which you retain consciousness.

entries.name: Stoneskin
entries: Your thick stone hide provides you with natural armor. While you aren't wearing armor, your base {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB} equals 13 plus your Dexterity modifier. You can use a {@item Shield|XPHB} and still gain this benefit.

race.name: Gnoll

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 7–8 feet tall)
As a Gnoll, you have these special traits.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have Darkvision with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Bite
entries: Your teeth are natural weapons, which you can use to make Unarmed Strikes. If you hit with them, you deal Piercing damage equal to 1d4 plus your Strength modifier in place of the normal Bludgeoning damage of your Unarmed Strike.

entries.name: Hunter's Senses
entries: You have proficiency in the Perception, Stealth, or Survival skill.

entries.name: Rampage
entries: When you use your Bite or reduce a creature to 0 Hit Points with an attack, you can use a Bonus Action to move up to half your Speed and make one attack with a weapon or an Unarmed Strike using your Bite.

race.name: Harpy

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5–6 feet tall)
As a Harpy, you have these special traits.

entries.name: Flight
entries: You have a Fly Speed equal to your Speed while you aren't wearing Medium or Heavy armor.

entries.name: Songbird
entries: You have proficiency in the Performance skill.

entries.name: Harpy's Charms
entries: You know the Friends cantrip and can cast it using only Verbal components in place of its usual components. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you select this species).

entries.name: Shadow's Magic
entries: If you have the Spellcasting or the Pact Magic class feature, the spells on the Harpy Spells table are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class. You can cast these spells using only Verbal components in place of their usual components.

entries.name: Shadow's Magic
entries: TODO: replace with group

Harpies and Medusas both possess a trait called Shadow's Magic, which adds a set of spells to the spell list of any spellcasting class. While these abilities are resolved exactly like spells, they are supposed to reflect enhanced aspects of the harpy's voice or the medusa's gaze. When a Medusa Wizard uses Shadow's Magic to cast Hypnotic Pattern, they might glare at a group of people, their eyes flaring in iridescent colors. When a Harpy casts Suggestion, they might sing their request, the insidious power of their voice making it a command. Because of this, spells cast in this way don't require all of the usual components. While this is only true for spells on the Shadow's Magic lists, a Harpy or Medusa spellcaster could describe other spells as being manifestations of their voice or gaze. A Medusa Cleric could describe her Guiding Bolt as emerging from her eyes, while a Harpy Bard casting Shatter could describe it as a deadly song. This provides no mechanical benefit, but it's a way to add unique flavor to a character and to present their magic as expanded gifts of the Shadow.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5–6 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Fearsome Presence
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Intimidation|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Serpentine
entries: You know {@language Serpentine|FoEQuickstone}, a sign language conveyed through the motion of the snakes atop your head. Serpentine has no written form and can only be utilized by medusas.

entries.name: Petrifying Gaze
entries: You know the {@spell Gray Gaze|FoEQuickstone} cantrip and can cast it without components. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you select this species). When you reduce a creature to 0 Hit Points with this spell, you can cause it to turn to stone. A creature turned to stone in this way has the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Medusa's Gift
entries: When you cast Gray Gaze, you can choose to augment it. If a creature fails its saving throw against the augmented spell, it has the Restrained condition for 1 minute instead of having Disadvantage on its next Dexterity saving throw. A Restrained target makes another Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. You must concentrate to maintain the effect. If you lose your Concentration, the creature no longer has the Restrained condition.
You can use this trait a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a Long Rest.

entries.name: Shadow's Magic
entries: If you have the Spellcasting or the Pact Magic class feature, the spells on the Medusa Spells table are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class. You can cast these spells without Material components.

entries.name: Shadow's Magic
entries: TODO: replace with group

Harpies and Medusas both possess a trait called Shadow's Magic, which adds a set of spells to the spell list of any spellcasting class. While these abilities are resolved exactly like spells, they are supposed to reflect enhanced aspects of the harpy's voice or the medusa's gaze. When a Medusa Wizard uses Shadow's Magic to cast Hypnotic Pattern, they might glare at a group of people, their eyes flaring in iridescent colors. When a Harpy casts Suggestion, they might sing their request, the insidious power of their voice making it a command. Because of this, spells cast in this way don't require all of the usual components. While this is only true for spells on the Shadow's Magic lists, a Harpy or Medusa spellcaster could describe other spells as being manifestations of their voice or gaze. A Medusa Cleric could describe her Guiding Bolt as emerging from her eyes, while a Harpy Bard casting Shatter could describe it as a deadly song. This provides no mechanical benefit, but it's a way to add unique flavor to a character and to present their magic as expanded gifts of the Shadow.

race.name: Warforged

sizeEntry.name: Size:
sizeEntry.entry: Medium (about 6–7 feet tall) or Small (about 3–4 feet tall), chosen when you select this species

entries: As a Warforged, you have these special traits.

entries.name: Constructed Resilience
entries: You were created to have remarkable fortitude, represented by the following benefits.

items: You have Resistance to Poison damage. You also have Advantage on saving throws you make to avoid or end the Poisoned condition.
You don't need to eat, drink, or breathe. You do not gain Exhaustion levels due to Dehydration, Malnutrition, or Suffocation.
You are immune to disease.
You don't need to sleep, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Integrated Protection
entries: Your body has built-in defensive layers, which can be enhanced with armor.

items: You gain a +1 bonus to Armor Class.

You can don only armor with which you have armor training. To don armor other than a Shield, you must incorporate it into your body over the course of 1 hour, during which you remain in contact with the armor. To doff armor, you must spend 1 hour removing it. You can rest while donning and doffing armor in this way.
While you live, the armor incorporated into your body can't be removed against your will.

entries.name: Sentry's Rest
entries: You can finish a Long Rest in 6 hours if you spend those hours in an inactive, motionless state, during which you retain consciousness.

entries.name: Specialized Design
entries: You gain proficiency in one skill and one tool of your choice.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have Darkvision with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have proficiency in the Perception skill, and you have Advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

entries.name: Bite
entries: Your formidable jaws are a natural weapon, which you can use to make Unarmed Strikes. If you hit with them, you deal Piercing damage equal to 1d8 plus your Strength modifier in place of the normal Bludgeoning damage of your Unarmed Strike.

entries.name: For the Pack
entries: You can use the Help action as a Bonus Action.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: Your dense fur and thick hide provide you with natural armor. While you aren't wearing armor, your base Armor Class equals 12 plus your Dexterity modifier.

entries.name: Quadruped
entries: You have several traits based on your quadrupedal body shape.

items: You cannot hold items in your paws, and you cannot wield weapons or a Shield unless otherwise noted in the weapon's description (see Steel Jaws).
You can perform the Somatic components of spells with your front paws.
You have Disadvantage on ability checks that require fine manipulation.
You can carry a rider of Medium size or smaller. You also count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity.
You cannot wear armor designed for humanoids, you must wear barding instead. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.
Any climb that requires hands is especially difficult for you. When you make such a climb, each foot of movement costs you 4 extra feet, instead of the normal 1 extra foot.

raceFluff.name: Gargoyle
entries: Gargoyles are indistinguishable from stone statues... until they move. In Eberron, the first gargoyles were carved by Dhakaani goblins, but it was the daelkyr Orlassk who brought them to life. The oldest gargoyles have been in a state of torpor for thousands of years. Now they have risen to carve out a place of their own in the new nation of Droaam.

Gargoyles are humanoids carved from stone. The horned, winged form often associated with the gargoyle is a common design; in Eberron the Dhakaani placed these fierce figures on fortresses. However, gargoyles don't have to have horns or wings, and they can alter their form over time. Gargoyles reproduce by imbuing a sliver of their life force into a stone and burying it in gravel; this seed assimilates mass from the loose stone and builds its final form.

Gargoyles have no need of food or drink. They are nearly immune to the passage of time and can remain standing still indefinitely. For any gargoyle, a fundamental question is why they choose to move at all. What drives them? There are a few common archetypes. Seekers are driven by curiosity, and love seeing new places and learning new things. Guardians devote themselves to protecting a person, place, or concept. Movers enjoy motion itself—flight, fighting, dancing—and often become scouts or soldiers. Thinkers are rarely seen, because they have the least reason to actually move; they live to ponder philosophies and ideas. A statue in a temple or a library could be a gargoyle priest or sage, lost in contemplation.

raceFluff.name: Gnoll
entries: Fierce and feral, the first gnolls were hyenas infused with malefic power by archfiends of war and the wild. They were created as cruel soldiers to serve in the endless conflicts of fiends, but over the course of countless generations a number of gnoll clans broke their ties to their demon overlords. These free gnolls are fiercely loyal to their pack and their clan, and serve as a stabilizing force within Droaam.

Gnolls that are bound to the overlords are vicious and wild. Those who have escaped this bondage still have a fiendish spark within, but they contain and control this power. Some learn to wield it as Warlocks. Others known as hwyri train to fight demons and other supernatural threats. Even free gnolls can be aggressive, but they are gifted hunters and fiercely loyal to those they choose as family.

raceFluff.name: Harpy
entries: Harpies blend avian and human elements, possessing functional wings and birdlike legs ending in clawed feet. But the most remarkable feature of a harpy is their voice. Arcane power flows through a harpy and into their words, allowing them to manipulate emotions and to charm even the most hardened of hearts. While there are always exceptions, most harpies are passionate and energetic; the power of their song reflects their own surging emotions. Most enjoy the freedom of flight, expressing themselves through sound and motion.

The passionate nature of the harpy is reflected in their devotion to family, friends, and causes. Some of the harpy flights of Droaam are the most loyal allies of the Daughters of Sora Kell, while others stubbornly oppose their plans for Droaam. When creating a harpy character, think about their driving passion and pursue it fiercely.

raceFluff.name: Medusa
entries: Medusas are infamous across Khorvaire for the deadly power of their petrifying gaze. The medusas of Cazhaak Draal are one of the most powerful forces within Droaam, renowned both for their remarkable stonework and their deep devotion to the Dark Six; the Cazhaak Creed has become the most widespread religion in Droaam. Medusas tend to be calm and calculating, useful traits when a single glance can have devastating consequences.

Medusa appearance varies by bloodline; some have scaled skin while at a glance others appear to be carved from stone. All medusas have a mane of writhing serpents, and they can use this mane to observe their surroundings even when they are blindfolded or have their main eyes closed. The petrifying gaze that medusa are famous for is something that develops over time. Young medusas have a weaker form known as the Gray Gaze, which eventually evolves into the Shadowswift Gaze that can petrify creatures in an instant.

raceFluff.name: Warforged
entries: Warforged are constructed humanoids, designed by skilled artificers and infused with the spark of life. Though they are made of wood and metal, warforged can feel pain and emotion. Built as weapons, they must now find a purpose beyond war. A warforged can be a steadfast ally, a cold-hearted killer, or a visionary in search of meaning.

Warforged are formed from a blend of organic and inorganic materials. Root-like cords infused with alchemical fluids serve as their muscles, wrapped around a framework of steel, darkwood, and stone. Armored plates form a protective outer shell; this armor can be changed and removed, but it's rare for this to be done. The warforged of Eberron share a common facial design, with a hinged jaw, crystal eyes, and a unique sigil engraved on the reinforced forehead. Beyond these common elements, the precise design of a warforged will vary depending on the purpose for which it was designed.

raceFluff.name: Worg
entries: While sometimes mistaken for large wolves, worgs are a unique species of canid predator possessing keen intelligence and the power of speech. Worg senses are sharper than those of humans, and they feel a deep connection to the natural world; they delight in scents and sounds that others around them may not even notice. The worgs of the Watching Wood are devoted to the Devourer and the Fury, and this faith encourages them to rely on their instincts and intuition, as well as taking joy in the hunt and strengthening their pack.

The worgs of the Watching Wood are more compact than some other strains of the species. They are Medium creatures, though they can pull heavy loads and carry a Medium creature as a rider. While they have no hands and typically have little interest in material goods, the smiths of Maenya's Fist have developed specialized armor for worgs, along with Steel Jaws that strengthen a worg's bite and which can be enchanted like any other weapon.

entries.name: Fiendish Legacy
entries: When you choose a legacy, you can select one of the options in the Eberron Fiendish Legacies table instead of one from the Player's Handbook.

entries.caption: Eberron Fiendish Legacies
rows: You have Resistance to Psychic damage. You also know the {@spell Vicious Mockery|XPHB} cantrip.
You have Resistance to Fire damage. You also know the {@spell Control Flames|XPHB} cantrip.

You have Resistance to one of the following damage types: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning. Whenever you finish a Long Rest, your Resistance randomly changes to one of these four damage types. You also know the {@spell Shocking Grasp|XPHB} cantrip.
You have Resistance to Necrotic damage. You also know the {@spell Chill Touch|XPHB} cantrip.
You have Resistance to Cold damage. You also know the {@spell Ray of Frost|XPHB} cantrip.
You have Advantage on all Wisdom saving throws against magic. You also know the {@spell Mage Hand|XPHB} cantrip.
You have training with Light and Medium armor and with Shields. You also know the {@spell Blade Ward|XPHB} cantrip.

subclass.name: College of Wands
subclassFeatures: Ain't Big Enough for the Both of Us|Bard|XPHB|Wands|FoEQuickstone|14

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Demonshard
entries: {@i Empower Yourself with a Fiendish Presence}

Demonglass holds the essence of a fiend—pure malefic power yearning for release. A painful, and often lethal, ritual can embed a shard of demonglass in a mortal's body; if the mortal survives, they can draw on the power of the fiend. The warriors of the Carrion Tribes in the Demon Wastes and the champions of Turakbar's Fist in Droaam are eager to augment their might in this way, but there are others—Znir hwyri, Ghaash'kala—who make this sacrifice in order to fight hellfire with hellfire. No matter their intention, a Barbarian who walks the Path of the Demonshard may struggle to keep the fiendish malice contained.

subclassFeature.name: Demontongue
entries: Your demonshard grants you innate understanding of the languages of fiends. You can speak and understand your choice of either Abyssal or Infernal.

subclassFeature.name: Fiendish Punishment
entries: The fiendish presence in your demonshard can punish your enemies. While your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1} is active, if you take damage from a creature that you can see within 60 feet of yourself, the creature takes {@damage 1d4} Fire or Necrotic damage (your choice). You can use this feature only once per turn.

In addition, if an allied creature within 10 feet of you takes damage from a creature that you can see within 60 feet of yourself, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to cause the damaging creature to take {@damage 1d4} Fire or Necrotic damage (your choice). The damage increases when you reach Barbarian levels 6 ({@dice 1d6}), 10 ({@dice 1d8}), 14 ({@dice 1d10}) and 20 ({@dice 1d12}).

subclassFeature.name: Just One Master
entries: The fiendish presence in your demonshard has grown, and it reacts badly to competition. While your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1} is active you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} and {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions, and you have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Psychic damage.

Additionally, if you take Psychic damage or if you make a saving throw to avoid or end the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} or {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions, you must use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, if available, to immediately enter a {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1}. Entering a {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1} in this way does not expend a use of your {@classFeature Rage|Barbarian|XPHB|1}.

subclassFeature.name: Overflowing Malice
entries: The evil in your demonshard has grown, and its power can escape when you are distracted by pain. When a creature triggers your {@subclassFeature Fiendish Punishment|Barbarian|XPHB|Demonshard|FoEQuickstone|3} feature, all other creatures within 10 feet of you take the damage too.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of Tyranny
entries: The fiendish presence in your demonshard revels in the pain it has wrought. When a creature takes damage from your {@subclassFeature Fiendish Punishment|Barbarian|XPHB|Demonshard|FoEQuickstone|3} or {@subclassFeature Overflowing Malice|Barbarian|XPHB|Demonshard|FoEQuickstone|10} features, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to cause one affected creature to make a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 plus your Constitution modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}). The creature suffers a -1 penalty to its saving throw for each other creature affected by {@subclassFeature Fiendish Punishment|Barbarian|XPHB|Demonshard|FoEQuickstone|3} or {@subclassFeature Overflowing Malice|Barbarian|XPHB|Demonshard|FoEQuickstone|10} on the same turn. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 1d10} Necrotic damage and has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. At the end of each of the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} creature's turns, the creature repeats the save (without a penalty), ending the effect on itself on a success.

subclassFeature.name: College of Wands
entries: {@i Wield Deadly Magic with Style and Panache}

For a Bard of the College of Wands, spellcasting is an art and every duel is a symphony. Whether they use their skills as Entertainers, Smugglers, or Spies, a Bard can draw applause from an audience even as they lay an enemy low with a distracting word, a perfect gesture, and a surge of arcane power.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Cantrip
entries: You know one cantrip of your choice from the {@filter Sorcerer spell list|spells|level=0|class=sorcerer} (see the Sorcerer class's section of the Player's Handbook for a list of Sorcerer spells). {@spell Fire Bolt|XPHB} is recommended. The cantrip counts as a Bard cantrip for you, but it doesn't count against the number of Bard cantrips you know.
Additionally, you can use a Wand, Rod, or Orb as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB} for your Bard spells.

subclassFeature.name: Wandslinger's Presence
entries: You know how to talk yourself up and tear your opponents down. If you speak to a creature for at least 1 minute, you can attempt to distract and rattle them when the call to action finally comes. If the creature rolls an {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count equal to or higher than your own, it must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature's {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} is reduced to be equal to yours, and it acts immediately after you in the {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} order.

subclassFeature.name: At Your Fingertips
entries: When you hit a creature with a Bard cantrip or when a creature fails a saving throw against one of your Bard cantrips, you can expend one use of your Bardic Inspiration to deal an extra {@damage 2d6} damage to that creature. You can do so only once per round, on your turn.
The extra damage increases when you reach Bard levels 5 ({@dice 3d6}), 10 ({@dice 5d6}) and 15 ({@dice 8d6}).

subclassFeature.name: Got Your Back
entries: You know how to cast with style, and your allies can take heart from your displays of grit or showmanship. If you expend a use of your Bardic Inspiration to improve the damage of a cantrip with your {@subclassFeature At Your Fingertips|Bard|XPHB|Wands|FoEQuickstone|3} feature, you can use your {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on the same turn to grant a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on the next saving throw it makes for 1 minute.

subclassFeature.name: Ain't Big Enough for the Both of Us
entries: Your wandplay is legendary, and your territory is assured. Whenever you expend a use of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|Bard|XPHB|1} or when a creature within 60 feet of you adds one of your Bardic Inspiration dice to a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, one creature of your choice that can see you within 60 feet of yourself must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn. If the target already has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition, it must immediately use its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, if available, to move as far as away from you as it can, using the safest route.

subclassFeature.name: Commerce Domain
entries: {@i Tip the Scales of Fate with Divine Gold}

Prayer may be the currency of the gods, but hard cash makes the world go round. Clerics of the Commerce Domain believe that society and economy are two sides of the same coin, and defending one's community means little if you don't have the resources and trade to back it up. As the Sovereign of World and Wealth, Kol Korran is the most common patron to Clerics of this domain, but those with a more selfish outlook might look to the Keeper to support their greed.

subclassFeature.name: Commerce Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this domain ensures you always have certain spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Commerce Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Commerce Domain Spells
rows: {@spell Augury}, {@spell Charm Person}, {@spell Comprehend Languages}, {@spell Locate Object}

subclassFeature.name: Divine Wealth
entries: Your spiritual savvy manifests as material wealth. When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you conjure two divine coins and lose any previously unspent divine coins. Whenever you make a saving throw against a magical effect caused by a hostile creature, you can choose to spend a divine coin or gain a divine coin. You must choose whether or not to spend a coin before you roll your save.

entries.name: Spend a Coin
entries: Roll a {@dice d4} and add the number rolled tothe saving throw.

entries.name: Gain a Coin
entries: Roll a {@dice d4} and subtract the number rolledfrom the saving throw.

The number of divine coins you conjure when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} changes when you reach certain Cleric levels. You conjure three at level 5, four at level 9, five at level 13, and six at level 17.

subclassFeature.name: Money Spinner
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you present your {@item Holy Symbol|XPHB} and expend a use of your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric|XPHB|2} to gain favor or turn away prying eyes. Choose a number of creatures within 30 feet of yourself equal to one plus one more for each divine coin you expend when you use this feature. For each target, choose either a bribe or a reward.

entries.name: Reward
entries: The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition for 1 minute or until it takes damage. While it has the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition, it is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} to you and other creatures you designate.

entries.name: Bribe
entries: The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target has the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition for 1 minute or until it takes damage.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Bargain
entries: Transactions are at the heart of your belief system, and you have learned to buy and sell metaphysical boons with your divine wealth. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can magically conduct a metaphysical trade with one creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself. Choose either Buy or Sell.

entries.name: Buy
entries: Give one of your divine coins to the target. It can spend the divine coin as if it had your {@subclassFeature Divine Wealth|Cleric|XPHB|Commerce|FoEQuickstone|3} feature. The target takes {@damage 1d8} Necrotic damage, and you or one creature that you can see within 30 feet of yourself regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the damage taken.

entries.name: Sell
entries: Gain a divine coin. You take {@damage 1d8} Necrotic damage, and the target regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the damage taken. The damage cannot be reduced by any means.

subclassFeature.name: Open Market
entries: When you use your {@subclassFeature Divine Bargain|Cleric|XPHB|Commerce|FoEQuickstone|6} feature, you roll {@dice 2d8} rather than {@dice 1d8} to determine how many {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} are regained or lost.

In addition, when you use your {@subclassFeature Divine Bargain|Cleric|XPHB|Commerce|FoEQuickstone|6} feature you can target up to six creatures you can see within 30 feet of yourself, buying or selling divine coins separately for each target. You use the same {@dice 2d8} roll to determine the {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} each creature regains or loses. If you target multiple creatures in this way, you cannot do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Bloodhound
entries: {@i Follow your Mark to the Bitter End}

Rangers recognise the primal connections between all living things, and as a Bloodhound you know precisely how to exploit them to track down your chosen prey. The Western Frontier is home to countless fugitives and war criminals, and House Tharashk trains its best bounty hunters to follow these ancient techniques— while on the other side of the Border Road, Znir hunters and worgs of the Great Pack use the skills of the Bloodhound to track enemies of Droaam.

subclassFeature.name: Bloodhound Spells
entries: When you reach a Ranger level specified in the Bloodhound Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Ley Line Tracker
entries: Given your knowledge of the landscape, you can use ley lines as conduits to stretch your magic over vast distances when tracking a target, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Mark Bounty
entries: Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can single out one creature as your bounty. To mark a creature as your bounty, you must have seen that creature or possess an object that has been in their possession for at least 24 hours. Once on each of your turns you can change your bounty to one creature you can see (no action required).

entries.name: Masterful Tracking
entries: Your Ranger spells of the Divination school can target your bounty at any distance, even if you cannot see them, unless your bounty is protected from Divination spells (as with {@spell Nondetection|XPHB}) or is on another plane of existence.

subclassFeature.name: Unwavering Attention
entries: When you hit your bounty or a creature currently marked by your {@spell Hunter's Mark|XPHB}, you deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage. You can deal this extra damage only once per turn. If you deal this damage as part of an {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB}, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} again from the start of the next creature's turn (instead of on your next turn).

subclassFeature.name: Relentless Pursuit
entries: If your bounty or a creature currently marked by your {@spell Hunter's Mark|XPHB} ends its turn more than 5 feet away from you and you can see it, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move your speed towards it. This movement does not provoke {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks}.

subclassFeature.name: Eyes on the Prize
entries: You focus everything on bringing your chosen target down. When you take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action and target only one creature with all your attacks, you can make an additional attack against that creature. If the additional attack is a melee attack and it hits, the target has either the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} or {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition (your choice). If the additional attack is a ranged attack and it hits, the target has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

subclassFeature.name: Nowhere to Hide
entries: Illusions and other magical concealments cannot hinder your pursuit. You can cast {@spell True Seeing|XPHB} on yourself without expending a spell slot or material components. If you do so, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Additionally, when you use your {@subclassFeature Ley Line Tracker|Ranger|XPHB|Bloodhound|FoEQuickstone|3} feature to target your bounty, you are not affected by magic that conceals your bounty from your Divination spells.

subclassFeature.name: Nemesis Sorcery
entries: {@i Devastate Foes with Speed and Precision}

While some sorcerers revel in unleashing devastation on dozens of enemies at once, you specialize in the arcane duel. You act with absolute precision, focusing your energy to strike at the perfect moment. You learn to break spells directed against you, whether expending your own power to fully counter them or casually dispersing deadly force. You may have learned the arts of magic on the battlefields of the Last War, but now you're the epitome of the lone wandslinger, always ready for the next duel.

subclassFeature.name: Nemesis Spells
entries: When you reach a Sorcerer level specified in the Nemesis Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Nemesis Spells
rows: {@spell Compelled Duel}, {@spell Mirror Image}, {@spell See Invisibility}, {@spell Shield}

subclassFeature.name: Readied Magic
entries: You have learned to hold back your magical power, prepared to unleash it when the time is just right. If you use an {@variantrule Action|XPHB} to Ready a spell, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws and ability checks until the start of your next turn. Additionally, if the trigger for your readied spell occurs, you can cast the readied spell without using your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}.

If the trigger does not resolve, if you choose not to act on the trigger, or if you lose {@status Concentration|XPHB} on the spell, you gain a number of Sorcery Points equal to the spell's level at the start of your next turn. You still expend the spell slot as normal.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Deflection
entries: When you take damage from a spell or other magical effect, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to halve the spell's damage against you.

subclassFeature.name: Always Ready
entries: You always have your next spell dancing on the tip of your tongue. You can use a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to Ready a spell as if you had used your {@variantrule Action|XPHB} to do so. If you expend a spell slot when you ready a spell in this way, it does not count against the usual limit of only one spell slot expended to cast a spell per turn.

Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} unless you spend 4 Sorcery Points (no action required) to restore your use of it.

subclassFeature.name: Mindset of Perfect Prediction
entries: You have learned to enter a focused state of mind. As an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}, you can activate your mindset of perfect prediction, gaining the benefits below. At the end of each of your turns, starting on the turn after you activated your mindset, you must make a Charisma saving throw (DC 8 plus your Charisma modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}). On a failed save, your mindset ends. If you are {@status Concentration|XPHB|Concentrating} on multiple spells when your mindset ends, you can choose one spell to maintain. The rest of the spells end as if your {@status Concentration|XPHB} had been broken. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Quickened Mind
entries: When rolling {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}, you may instead choose an {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} count of 31.

entries.name: Expansive Mind
entries: You can concentrate on any number of spells simultaneously. If you are forced to make a saving throw to maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB} while you are {@status Concentration|XPHB|Concentrating} on multiple spells, you make only a single Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, your {@status Concentration|XPHB} breaks on all spells.

entries.name: Predictive Mind
entries: You have {@spell Counterspell|XPHB} prepared. You can cast it as a 6th-level spell without expending a spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Stone Sovereign Patron
entries: {@i Hear the Whispering of the Stones}

You have listened to the will of the stone, and made a pact with one of Eberron's great earthen powers. The whispers of the daelkyr Orlassk corrupt many Warlocks to their cause, but similar magics may be the gifts of the greedy fey King Grayfinger or even the medusa Queen Sheshka of Cazhaak Draal. The gnomes of Lorghalan draw their power from their friendship with the earth elementals of their island; perhaps you have made peace with the earth itself.

subclassFeature.name: Eternity in Stone
entries: When you reduce a creature to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, you can cause it to turn to stone. If you do so, you gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to {@dice 1d10} + your Warlock level. A creature turned to stone in this way has the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Stone Speaker
entries: Your pact grants you the ability to commune with earth and stone. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you imbue stones in an immobile 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} with limited sentience, giving them the ability to communicate with you. You can question stones about events in the spell's area within the past day, gaining information about creatures that have passed, items that might have been removed from the area, and other circumstances.

If an earth Elemental or a creature with the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition is in the area, you can communicate with it as if you shared a language, but you gain no magical ability to influence it.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Stone Sovereign Spells
entries: The magic of your patron ensures you always have certain spells ready; when you reach a Warlock level specified in the Stone Sovereign Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

entries.caption: Stone Sovereign Spells
rows: {@spell Absorb Elements|XGE}, {@spell Earthbind|XGE}, {@spell Earth Tremor|XGE}, {@spell Spike Growth}

subclassFeature.name: Form of Stone
entries: Stone is no prison to you. Whenever you have the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition, you are aware of your surroundings and you have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage.

Additionally, you have learned to take on a stone form to protect yourself from injury. As a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} when you take damage, you can give yourself the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition until the start of your next turn. The {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition applies before you take the triggering damage, possibly granting {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} or {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to that damage. When the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition ends, you can choose to emerge from a stone surface into an unoccupied space you can see within 30 feet of yourself.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Stone's Embrace
entries: You always have the {@spell Meld into Stone|XPHB} spell prepared. When you cast {@spell Meld into Stone|XPHB}, you can choose up to five willing creatures within 5 feet of you to also gain the benefits of the spell. Each creature must be touching a stone object or surface large enough to fully contain their body. Affected creatures can end the effect on themselves early by using 5 feet of movement to leave the stone where they entered it.

Creatures who finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} while under the effect of your {@spell Meld into Stone|XPHB} spell gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} against the first instance of damage they take after leaving the stone.

subclassFeature.name: Stone Servant
entries: You gain the ability to control the actions of {@condition Petrified|XPHB} creatures, while bestowing upon them the power of your patron. One creature with the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition that you touch becomes an {@creature Elemental Spirit|XPHB|Earth Elemental Spirit} under your control as if you had cast the {@spell Summon Elemental|XPHB} spell at 6th-level. The creature's size does not change and you do not need to maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB}. The transformation lasts until a {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} spell is cast on the creature, until the Elemental Spirit is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, or until you use this feature again.

feat.name: Lesser Dragonmark
entries: You possess a Lesser Dragonmark, which is visible somewhere on your body. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Manifest Dragonmark
entries: You manifest a dragonmark. Your choice of Mark is restricted by your species, as shown in the Least Dragonmark Benefit table. Your choice of Mark determines the skills, tools, and spells you gain, as given in the same table. When you select this feat, choose Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma as your spellcasting ability for the feat's cantrip(s) and spells.

entries.name: Guidance of the Mark
entries: You add 1d4 to any ability check you make using the skills or tools associated with your Mark.

entries.name: Cantrip
entries: You learn the cantrip(s) associated with your Mark. The Mark of Handling and Mark of Warding don't grant a cantrip; instead, each Mark grants three Spells of the Mark.

entries.name: Spells of the Mark
entries: Your dragonmark grants you access to the spells associated with your Mark. You always have these spells prepared, and you can cast each of them once at their lowest level without expending a spell slot. When you do so, you can't cast them in this way again until you finish a Long Rest. To cast any of these spells at a higher level or a second time prior to finishing a Long Rest, you must expend a spell slot.

entries.caption: Lesser Dragonmark Benefit
rows: {@spell Detect Poison and Disease|XPHB}, {@spell See Invisibility|XPHB}
{@spell Locate Animals and Plants|XPHB}, {@spell Locate Object|XPHB}
{@spell Animal Friendship|XPHB}, {@spell Beast Sense|XPHB}, {@spell Speak with Animals|XPHB}
{@skill Persuasion|XPHB}, {@item Brewer's Supplies|XPHB} or {@item Cook's Utensils|XPHB}
{@spell Calm Emotions|XPHB}, {@spell Purify Food and Drink|XPHB}
{@spell Comprehend Languages|XPHB}, {@spell Illusory Script|XPHB} (no Material component required)

feat.name: Ashbound Initiate
entries: You have learned a certain number of the secrets and techniques of the Ashbound druidic order. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Increase your Wisdom or Charisma score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries.name: Ashbound Proficiencies
entries: You gain proficiency in the Intimidation skill.

entries.name: Arcane Enmity
entries: When a creature you can see casts a spell, you have Advantage on attack rolls against that creature until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Ashbound Spells
entries: If you have the Spellcasting or the Pact Magic class feature, the spells on the Ashbound Spells table are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class.

feat.name: Gatekeeper Initiate
entries: You have learned a certain number of secrets and techniques of the Gatekeeper druidic order. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Increase your Wisdom or Charisma score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries.name: Gatekeeper Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Arcana|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Protection Against Aberrations
entries: When you make a saving throw against the magic abilities of an Aberration or a spell cast by an Aberration, you can roll 1d4 and add it to your saving throw.

entries.name: Gatekeeper Spells
entries: If you have the Spellcasting or the Pact Magic class feature, the spells on the Gatekeeper Spells table are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class.

feat.name: Greensinger Initiate
entries: You have learned a certain number of secrets and techniques of the Greensinger druidic order. You gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Increase your Wisdom or Charisma score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries.name: Greensinger's Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Performance|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Fey Dancer
entries: Whenever you cause a creature to gain the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition, you can join them in dance and revelry. If you do so, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move up to half your Speed without provoking {@variantrule Opportunity Attacks|XPHB}.

entries.name: Fey Affinity
entries: Your spells and magical abilities that affect Humanoids also affect Fey

entries.name: Greensinger Spells
entries: If you have the Spellcasting or the Pact Magic class feature, the spells on the Greensinger Spells table are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class.

feat.name: Hewn for Battle
entries: You have reshaped your stone body to be a more effective and devastating weapon of war. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Increase your Strength or Constitution score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries.name: Thickened Hide
entries: When you finish a Short or Long Rest, you can choose the thickness of your natural armor. While you aren't wearing armor, your base Armor Class becomes your choice of either 14 plus your Dexterity modifier, or 18. You can use a Shield and still gain this benefit.

entries.name: Spellcarving
entries: Your hide can be enchanted or infused as if it were nonmagical armor.

entries.name: Claws
entries: You have shaped your hands into fearsome claws. Your claws are natural weapons, which you can use to make Unarmed Strikes. If you hit with them, you deal Slashing damage equal to 1d6 plus your Strength modifier in place of the normal Bludgeoning damage of your Unarmed Strike.

feat.name: Orb Expert
entries: Your skill with magical Orbs helps you evade enemies while overcoming their defenses. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Fortune Teller
entries: When you finish a Short or Long Rest, roll 1d6 and record the result. When you cast a spell using an Orb as a Spellcasting Focus, you can add the result of this prescience roll to your spell attack roll, or reduce one target's saving throw by that amount. You must choose to do so before the attack roll or saving throw.
Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you finish a Short or Long Rest. Unused prescience rolls are lost when you finish a Short or Long Rest.

entries.name: See the Path
entries: While you are holding an Orb, Opportunity Attacks against you have Disadvantage.

entries.name: Prescient Escape
entries: While you are holding an Orb, whenever a creature you can see enters a space within 5 feet of you, you can use your Reaction to move up to your Speed without provoking an Opportunity Attack.

feat.name: Rod Expert
entries: You've mastered the use of a rod as an Arcane Focus. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Close-Ranged Focus
entries: If the target of a cantrip you cast using a Rod as a Spellcasting Focus is within 20 feet of you when you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2.

entries.name: Unshakeable Casting
entries: When you make a ranged spell attack roll while using a Rod as a Spellcasting Focus, you do not have Disadvantage on the roll if you are within 5 feet of an enemy.

entries.name: Rough & Tumble
entries: When you make a ranged spell attack while using a Rod as a Spellcasting Focus, you can use a Bonus Action to make a melee attack with your Rod. It counts as a Club for the purposes of the attack.

feat.name: Shadow's Gift of Stone
entries: You have learned to channel arcane power through your gaze. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Increase your Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries.name: Innate Magic
entries: When you reach a character level specified in the Shadow's Gift of Stone Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared. You can cast each of these spells once without expending a spell slot, and you must finish a Long Rest before you can cast them in this way again. You can also cast these spells using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Your spellcasting ability for these spells is the same as the spellcasting ability you chose for your Petrifying Gaze trait.

feat.name: Staff Expert
entries: You've unlocked the deadly ranged potential of the Staff. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Arcane Artillery
entries: When you cast a spell that has a range of 5 feet or greater using a Staff as your Spellcasting Focus, you can use a Bonus Action to double the range of the spell.

entries.name: Powerful Focus
entries: When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for a cantrip you cast using a Staff as a Spellcasting Focus, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2.

entries.name: Explosive Casting
entries: If all targets of a spell you cast using a Staff as your Spellcasting Focus are more than half the spell's range from you, one creature of your choice that you hit with a spell attack or that fails a saving throw against the spell has the Prone condition.

feat.name: Stone Eyes
entries: Your Petrifying Gaze has come into its own. If a creature that has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} or {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB} condition as a result of one of your spells or your Medusa's Gift trait fails a saving throw to end the effect by 5 or more, you can choose to turn that creature to stone. Any magical effects causing the creature to have the Restrained or Paralyzed condition end, and the creature has the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. You must concentrate to maintain the effect. If you lose your {@variantrule Concentration|XPHB}, the Petrified condition ends.

If you maintain your Concentration on the effect for the entire possible duration, the target is {@condition Petrified|XPHB} until the condition is ended by {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB} or similar magic.

feat.name: Voice of the Fury
entries: The mystical power of your voice grows stronger. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Increase your Dexterity, Wisdom, or Charisma score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries.name: Innate Magic
entries: When you reach a character level specified in the Voice of the Fury Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared. You can cast each of these spells once without expending a spell slot, and you must finish a Long Rest before you can cast them in this way again. You can also cast these spells using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Your spellcasting ability for these spells is the same as the spellcasting ability you chose for your Harpy's Charms trait.

feat.name: Wand Expert
entries: You are adept with the use of Wands as a swift Spellcasting Focus. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Wand Mastery
entries: If you make a spell attack using a Wand as a Spellcasting Focus, you gain Advantage on the attack roll if the target hasn't taken a turn.

entries.name: Unshakeable Casting
entries: When you make a ranged spell attack roll while using a Wand as a Spellcasting Focus, you do not have Disadvantage on the roll if you are within 5 feet of an enemy.

entries.name: Arcane Quickdraw
entries: Drawing or stowing a Wand does not count against the number of object interactions you can take for free on your turn.

feat.name: Warden Initiate
entries: You have learned some of the secrets and techniques of the Wardens of the Wood druidic order. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Increase your Wisdom or Charisma score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries.name: Warden's Proficiency.
entries: You gain proficiency in the Animal Handling skill.

entries.name: Protect Ally
entries: When a creature you can see hits another creature within 5 feet of you with an attack roll, you can take a Reaction to reduce the damage dealt to the target by 1d6 + your Proficiency Bonus.
Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you finish a Short or Long Rest.

entries.name: Warden Spells
entries: If you have the Spellcasting or the Pact Magic class feature, the spells on the Wardens of the Wood Spells table are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class.

feat.name: Wings of Stone
entries: You have manifested stone wings and achieved mastery of the air. You have a Fly Speed equal to your Speed.

feat.name: Winter Initiate
entries: You have learned some of the secrets and techniques of the Children of Winter druidic order. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Increase your Wisdom or Constitution score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries.name: Life from Death
entries: Whenever you take Necrotic damage, you gain Temporary Hit Points equal to your Proficiency Bonus after you take the damage.

entries.name: Summon Decay
entries: When you conjure a creature with a spell or magical ability, you can choose for that creature to be Undead instead of its usual creature type.

entries.name: Understand Disease
entries: You have Advantage on ability checks to research, diagnose, and treat disease.

entries.name: Children of Winter Spells
entries: If you have the Spellcasting or the Pact Magic class feature, the spells on the Children of Winter Spells table are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class.

feat.name: Wandslinger
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Arcane Aim
entries: You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls you make with spells.

entries.name: Mystic Force
entries: When you cast a cantrip that requires the target to make a saving throw, increase the DC of the saving throw by 1.

spell.name: Gray Gaze

components.m: a pebble with a hole in it

entries: You turn your gaze on one creature you can see within range. If the target can see your eyes, their body stiffens and cracks as if it were turning to stone. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take Necrotic damage equal to your Proficiency Bonus and have Disadvantage on the next Dexterity saving throw it makes before the end of its next turn.

spell.name: Orien Step
entries: You teleport up to five feet to an unoccupied space you can see. You cannot teleport through solid objects or out of manacles and similar restraints.

item.name: Steel Jaws
entries: Because they have no hands, worgs cannot wield weapons in the same way that most player characters can. However, worgs can wield a specially designed Martial Melee weapon called "Steel Jaws." Only Worgs can wield Steel Jaws, fitting as they do over a Worg's teeth. A Worg cannot use its Bite trait while it is wielding Steel Jaws.

item.name: Beggar's Wisdom
entries: The wit and wisdom of Beggar Dane is considered to be one of the national treasures of Breland. This small leatherbound book is a comprehensive, enchanted edition of his proverbs and advice. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action while holding this book, you can declare your desire for assistance with a particular task, causing the book to open to a page containing a quip or mote of wisdom that is strangely relevant to the situation at hand. You add {@dice 1d4} to the next ability check you make within the next minute. Once this property is used, you cannot benefit from any copy of {@i Beggar's Wisdom} until the next dawn.

item.name: Daff's Wonderful Draught
entries: Daff d'Jorasco's eclectic style of medicine produces similarly eclectic brews. This potion is a magic item. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can drink it or administer it to another creature within 5 of yourself. The creature that drinks this potion must roll on the following table to determine the effect:

entries.caption: Potion Effects
rows: You gain the effects of the {@spell Detect Thoughts|XPHB} spell for 1 minute or until you lose your {@variantrule Concentration|XPHB}. The save DC is 13.
You gain the effects of the {@spell Haste|XPHB} spell for 1 minute or until you lose your {@variantrule Concentration|XPHB}.
You must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or suffer the effects of the {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter|XPHB} spell for 1 minute.

item.name: Dry Spell
entries: This desiccated {@item Spell Scroll|XPHB} seems to draw the moisture from your fingertips. Its cipher is ineffable, and while its meaning becomes clear as you read the runes, clarity slips away should you try to transcribe it.

As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can use the scroll to cast {@spell Control Water|XPHB} without providing any Material components. The spell save DC is 15. In addition to the usual effects of the {@spell Control Water|XPHB} spell, any water manipulated by the spell is destroyed when the spell ends. Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and it crumbles to dust. If the casting is interrupted, the scroll is not lost.

item.name: Duelist's Scorecard
entries: This scrap of paper bears a table with space for five names. If you write a creature's name in one of the blank spaces on the table, it will shuffle the text to show their ranking as a duelist relative to all the other individuals named on the table. This appears to be calculated based on the number of duels the named individuals have won over the past year. The source of these scorecards and the rankings remains a mystery, but it appears to be linked to the Infinite Archive of Daanvi. Once all the spaces on the scorecard are filled, you cannot reveal the ranking of another name for 1 week, when all the names are magically erased.

item.name: Flashdraw Wand
entries: This delicate Wand hums with bound potential, and seems drawn to your fingers. While attuned to it, you cannot be {@status Surprised|XPHB}. Additionally, whenever you roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} you can choose to immediately draw this wand (no action required). If you do so, you can roll {@dice 1d4} and add the total to your {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} score, and all creatures within 5 feet of you take 1 Lightning damage.

item.name: Jury's Squeaky Wheel
entries: This magic Shield resembles a wooden wagon wheel. Writing inscribed on its inner rim indicates the shield was crafted by Jury d'Cannith, Quickstone's premier artificer, to prove a point to her wife.

As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} while holding this shield, you can grant {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to your level to the humanoid creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself that has the fewest {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. If creatures you can see within range are tied for the fewest {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, you can choose which of those creatures gains the {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

item.name: Lightning Runner
entries: This 10-foot-wide, 10-foot-long, 6-inch-thick platform of wood and steel levitates 5 feet off the ground and remains horizontal so long as it is within 20 feet of an operational track of lightning rail conductor stones. The platform can carry up to 2000 pounds. If it becomes overloaded, it drops to the ground, unable to levitate.

The platform is equipped with a 'pump' in its center that can be used to move it along the track of conductor stones. As a Magic action, a creature touching the pump can expend a spell slot of 1st-level or higher to cause the platform to continuously move either forwards or backwards along the conductor stone track at a speed of 30 feet. A creature with the Mark of Passage does not need to expend a spell slot to cause the platform to move.

Once moving, the platform will move in the chosen direction for one hour, or until a creature touching the pump uses a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to cause the platform to stop. If stopped in this way, a creature must expend another spell slot as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to start the platform moving again.

If the platform encounters an obstacle while moving, it will continue to push against the obstacle unless stopped with a {@action Magic|XPHB} action. Obstacles that weigh less than the total weight of the platform and its cargo will be pushed in front of the platform.

item.name: Misthaven Miscellany
entries: This small embroidered pouch is said to contain the cast-off goods discarded by the Merchant of Misthaven, an archfey of Thelanis. When you reach into the pouch, you can pull out a random trinket (see page 46 of the 2024 version of the fifth edition Player's Handbook or any other random trinket table of your choice). A trinket pulled from this pouch disappears when you pull another trinket from the pouch.

item.name: Quickstone Boomstick
entries: Whenever you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher using this Rod as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB}, you can choose to release its power in a thunderous burst. All creatures within 5 feet of you (including you) must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, affected creatures take {@damage 1d4} Thunder damage for each level of the spell you cast, and are {@condition Deafened|XPHB} until the end of their next turn.

item.name: Sandstorm Staff
entries: Many of the discarded weapons of the Last War have found their way into the hands of the people of the Barrens. This sliver of a broken Siege Staff can deliver a powerful punch when it needs to, but ejects an exhaust of swirling dust when exerted.
This staff can be wielded as a magic Quarterstaff. The staff has 10 charges and regains {@dice 1d6 + 4} expended charges daily at dawn.

When you cast a spell using this Staff as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB}, you can expend 1 charge to gain a +1 bonus to all spell attack rolls you make for that spell. If you do so, the staff conjures a 5-foot diameter vortex of dust in your space. At the start of each of your turns, roll a {@dice d20} for each dust vortex the staff has created. On a roll of 11 or higher, the dust vortex moves 5 feet in a random direction. On a roll of 10 or less, the dust vortex disappears.

Any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of any of the dust vortexes must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, an affected creature takes {@damage 1d4} Bludgeoning damage and is {@condition Blinded|XPHB} until the end of its turn.

item.name: Sarkaas' Gladrags
entries: Deven Sarkaas of Littlehand Haberdashers in Quickstone knows all too well how important it is to look one's best... and how 'best' can be very different depending on who (or what) you're meeting with. Deven stitched this fine cloak and sent it to Graywall to be enchanted, only to lose track of the garment on the return journey.

As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} while wearing the cloak, you can speak its command word to transform your outfit into finely crafted garments appropriate to the culture of one creature of your choice that you can see. Regardless of its appearance, the outfit can't be anything but clothing. Although it can duplicate the look of other magical clothing, the outfit doesn't gain its magical properties.

item.name: Scale of Kethelrax
entries: This Dagger is said to have been created by Kethelrax the Cunning, the kobold warlord of Shaarat Kol. Its short, crimson blade resembles a red dragon's scale, and tiny flames dance along its edge.

While you are holding this Dagger, you can use it as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB} for your spells. Additionally, you can cast {@spell Fire Bolt|XPHB} as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, using Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma (you choose when you Attune to the dagger) as the spellcasting ability.
Whenever you hit with a weapon attack using this Dagger, you can choose to deal Fire damage instead of Piercing damage.

item.name: Shock and Ore
entries: This pair of rough and ready War Picks are said to have been created by the first miners to quarry quickstone in the Barrens. They have long been passed around as heirlooms and rewards. These magical picks are a single magic item for the purposes of {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB}.
You gain the following benefits while wielding both picks:

items: The picks have the Light weapon property.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with the picks.
The picks have 3 charges, which they share. They regain {@dice 1d3} expended charges daily at dawn.

When you hit a target with a Melee attack using Shock, you can expend 1 charge as a bonus action to deal an additional {@damage 2d8} Lightning damage. A creature affected by this damage can't take Reactions until the start of its next turn.
When you hit a target with a Melee attack using Ore, you can expend 1 charge to cast {@spell Earth Tremor|XGE} XGE as a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, centered on the target.

item.name: Three-Faced Coin
entries: This gold piece appears to be a normal coin, with the crown of Galifar on one side and the Octogram of the Sovereign Host on the other. However, when flipped, it will land with one of three different symbols showing, each corresponding to one of the patrons of the Three Faces of Coin: Kol Korran, Onatar, and Kol Turrant (the Keeper). When you flip the coin, you can will the coin to land displaying a face of your choice. Once this property is used, you cannot do so again until the next dawn.

While this item doesn't require a command word or {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB}, the ability must be consciously triggered; if you've never used a Three-faced coin before, you must spend a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB} studying it to learn how to activate it. After being flipped, the coin returns to its usual two faces when a creature next touches it.

item.name: Thunder Coach
item.reqAttune: by a creature with the mark of passage
entries: The Thunder Coach is the workhorse of Orien's overland shipping, sometimes referred to as "galleons of the road." A product of the Twelve, it incorporated members of Kundarak, Cannith, and Orien in the design. A typical coach is a 10-foot-wide, 40-foot-long, 15-foot-high (including the wheels) vessel of wood and steel. When pulled by a large team (typically eight tribex), a coach can maintain a speed of up to five miles per hour. However, if someone with the Mark of Passage attunes to the coach and sits in the driver's seat, the full magic of the Thunder Coach comes into play. Under such conditions, four strong beasts can pull the coach at a steady pace of ten miles an hour. If it is moving along an Orien trade road, the effect is further amplified, allowing a top speed of 15 miles per hour. This requires the driver to remain seated and to maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB}, as if casting a spell. However, beyond these limitations, they are capable of conversation and other actions.

The forward fifteen feet of the coach holds a small cabin for up to three crew members. The crew of a coach typically includes one marked driver and two crew members who serve as both guards and cargo haulers. One of these haulers is usually a Vadalis- trained (though unmarked) handler who cares for the beasts. The top of the coach has positions at the front and back where archers or wandslingers can be stationed with {@variantrule Cover|XPHB|Half Cover}.

A typical Thunder Coach has two cargo chambers; one magical and one mundane. The back gate of a Thunder Coach opens to grant access to an extradimensional space that functions in the same way as a {@item Bag of Holding|XDMG}. When closed, the gate is typically sealed with an Arcane Lock linked to a password known to the driver. The mouth of the extradimensional space is 10-feet-wide by 10-feet-high. The size of the extradimensional space varies based on the model of the coach; the standard is 20-feet-wide, 15-feet-high, and 50-feet-deep. The system maintaining the extradimensional space takes up the final five feet of the coach.

Objects that produce extradimensional spaces (such as Bags of Holding, Portable Holes, or House Cannith's Crates of Containing) cannot cross the threshold of the rear compartment. For this reason, and to allow the transport of living creatures, the Thunder Coach also has a standard cargo compartment accessed from the side of the vehicle; this space is 10-feet-wide, 10-feet- high, and 20-feet-long.

item.name: Brand of Tyranny
entries: One end of this heavy, black iron Rod glows as if hot. Rather than burning red and orange, it shines a sickly shade of purple.
While holding this Rod, you gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls and to the saving throw DCs of your spells.

Whenever you touch a creature with this Rod, that creature must succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw or be branded with the mark of Tol Kharash, the overlord known as the Horned King. Whenever a branded creature makes an attack roll or a saving throw against being {@condition Frightened|XPHB}, the creature must roll a {@dice d4} and subtract the number rolled from the attack roll or saving throw. The brand lasts until the next dawn or it is removed with Remove {@variantrule Curses|XPHB|Curse} or Greater Restoration.

item.name: Demonglass Orb
entries: Red and black flames flicker behind the rough cut facets of this heavy demonglass shard. Memories of the Ages of Demons are bound within, and spellcasters who dare channel their magic through it find themselves and their targets visited by visions of that terrible past.

Whenever you cast a Divination spell using this Orb as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB}, you can give up some of your life force to reduce the saving throw of one creature affected by your spell. Roll 1 to 4 d6s; the resulting total is how much Necrotic damage you take. This damage can't be reduced in any way. The target has its saving throw reduced by 1 for each {@damage d6} of damage you take. You must decide how many dice to roll before the DM says whether the target succeeds or fails.

item.name: Kharash's Promise
entries: Tol Kharash, the Horned King, overlord of tyranny, demands that his minions revel in domination, fear, and the suffering of the downtrodden. During his campaigns in the Age of Demons, Tol Kharash shaped an artifact that would announce his coming across the Barrens; a harbinger of cruelty.

Kharash's Promise is a 3-foot long warhorn forged of demonglass and black iron. A trickle of boiling blood constantly drips from its widest end. While holding this Horn, you gain a +3 bonus to spell attack rolls and to the saving throw DCs of your Bard spells.

entries.name: Random Properties.
entries: This Artifact has the following random properties, which you can determine by rolling on the tables in the "Artifacts" section of the Dungeon Master's Guide:

items: 2 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Beneficial Properties|XDMG|minor beneficial} properties
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Major Beneficial Properties|XDMG|major beneficial} property
2 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Detrimental Properties|XDMG|minor detrimental} properties

entries.name: Surety of Dominance
entries: While attuned to the warhorn, no creature can assert its influence over you. You cannot be {@condition Charmed|XPHB} or {@condition Frightened|XPHB}. If a creature targets you with a magical effect that would cause you to be {@condition Charmed|XPHB} or {@condition Frightened|XPHB}, that creature takes {@damage 4d10} Psychic damage.

entries.name: Thaumaturgic Clarion
entries: If you blow Kharash's Promise, the sound it produces can be heard by all creatures within 1 mile.

entries.name: Promised End
entries: As a Magic action when you blow the horn, you can choose one creature that you can see and that can hear the horn to suffer a painful and inevitable end. The target must make a DC 20 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the target's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} maximum is reduced by 1 at the start of each of its turns until it dies, you die, you are no longer on the same plane of existence as the target, or the effect is ended with a {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell. Once this property is used, you cannot do so again until 13 days have passed.
As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} while affected, the target can choose to confront the source of its inevitable end, teleporting to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you.

item.name: Ink's Aide
entries: This colorful, jellyfish-like blob has been carefully cultivated by Quickstone's schoolmaster, Tragomir "Ink" Narathun, to impart a full curriculum to its host—though he has yet to convince anyone to partake. To attune to this item, you must hold it to one ear for the full {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} period, during which time its stringy tentacles reach inside your ear canal and secure the aide in place. The symbiont does not impair your hearing while it is attached.

entries.name: Spells
entries: The symbiont has 4 charges. You can use a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast one of the following spells (save DC 15) from it: {@spell Enhance Ability|XPHB} (2 charges) or {@spell Comprehend Languages|XPHB} (1 charge).
The symbiont regains {@dice 1d4} expended charges daily at dawn.

entries.name: Symbiotic Nature
entries: The aide can't be removed from you while you're attuned to it, and you can't voluntarily end your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to it. If you're targeted by a spell that ends a curse, your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to the aide ends, and it detaches from your ear.

item.name: Living Stoneskin
entries: This Plate Armor appears to be made of stone slabs carved with alien symbols. It is strangely warm to the touch. To attune to this item, you must wear it for the entire {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} period, during which the stone plates fuse with your skin.

While wearing this armor, you have a +1 bonus to {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB}, and you have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to nonmagical Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing damage. Additionally, the armor hardens under extreme impact; if you take 20 or more nonmagical Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage from one damage roll (after accounting for your {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB}), you are {@condition Petrified|XPHB} until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: # Symbiotic Nature
entries: The armor can't be removed from you while you're attuned to it, and you can't voluntarily end your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to it. If you're targeted by a spell that ends a curse, your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to the armor ends, and it detaches from you.

The armor requires fresh blood be fed to it. Immediately after you finish any {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you must either feed half of your remaining Hit Dice to the armor (round up) or take 1 level of {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB}.

item.name: Orlassk's Reach
entries: Despite being separated from its original owner, the lost arm of the daelkyr Orlassk can grant its wielder a sliver of the Lord of Stone's magic; enough power to reshape the world. To attune to this symbiont, you must hold it against one of your arms for the full {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} period, during which time its stone skin softens and envelops your limb.

entries.name: Random Properties
entries: This Artifact has the following random properties, which you can determine by rolling on the tables in the "Artifacts" section of the Dungeon Master's Guide:

items: 2 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Beneficial Properties|XDMG|minor beneficial} properties
2 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Detrimental Properties|XDMG|minor detrimental} properties
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Major Beneficial Properties|XDMG|major beneficial} property
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Major Detrimental Properties|XDMG|major detrimental} property

entries.name: # Voice of the Daelkyr
entries: You can speak with any Aberration as if you shared a language.

entries.name: # Command Aberration
entries: As a Magic action, you can cast {@spell Dominate Monster|XPHB} on an Aberration (save DC 18). Once this property is used, you cannot do so again until the next dawn.

entries.name: # Petrifying Touch
entries: The power of the stone shaper flows from you—despite what you may will. Any creature that you touch with your stone fingertips is affected as if you had cast {@spell Flesh to Stone|XPHB} (spell save DC 18). You do not need to concentrate on the effect, and you cannot choose to end it.

entries.name: # Stone Speaking
entries: As a Magic action, you imbue stones in an immobile 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} with limited sentience, giving them the ability to communicate with you. You can question stones about events in the effects area within the past day, gaining information about creatures that have passed, items that might have been removed from the area, and other circumstances. If an earth elemental or {@condition Petrified|XPHB} creature is in the area, you can communicate with it as if you shared a common language, but you gain no magical ability to influence it.

entries.name: # Greater Symbiotic Nature
entries: The arm can't be removed from you while you're attuned to it, and you can't voluntarily end your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to it. Your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to the arm can only be ended by a {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell.

item.name: Quickstone Whisperer
entries: This ancient, heavy marble torc is strangely warm to the touch. Though it resembles stone jewelry, the torc is in fact a simple symbiont which grants a limited form of control over earth and the ability to manipulate quickstone without the usual rituals. To attune to it, you must wear it around your neck for the full {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} period, during which time it coils around your throat like a snake.
While wearing the torc, you can use a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to transform a 5-foot cube of quickstone between its soft and wet forms, or irreversibly change it into its fixed form.

entries.name: # Spells
entries: As an {@variantrule Action|XPHB}, you can use the symbiote to cast {@spell Mold Earth|XGE} XGE or Meld into Stone. Once you use the torc to cast {@spell Meld into Stone|XPHB}, the spell can't be cast in this way until the next dusk.

entries.name: # Symbiotic Nature
entries: The torc can't be removed from you while you're attuned to it, and you can't voluntarily end your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to it. If you're targeted by a spell that ends a curse, your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to the torc ends, and it uncoils from around your neck.

item.name: Barghest Collar
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} when you bark the command word, you can transform from your worg form into a goblin form with your choice of physical characteristics, including age, sex, skin color, hair color, and voice. While transformed, your size is Small and you lose your Quadruped and Bite traits. Otherwise, your statistics don't change.

You can maintain the transformation for up to 4 hours, all at once or in several shorter periods, each one using a minimum of 1 minute of the duration. The collar regains 2 hours of transformation time for every 12 hours it isn't in use.

item.name: Cazhaak Eyeblinders
